metadata.titleEn: Prevalence and potential risk factors of self-reported diabetes among elderly people in China: A national cross-sectional study of 224,142 adults dataset (2015.08-2022.09)
metadata.description: The 4th China Urban Rural Elderly Population Survey was conducted in August 2015, which was a nationwide cross-sectional survey that included 224142 elderly people aged 60 and above in China. We assessed the incidence of diabetes and related conditions through descriptive analysis and chi square analysis of demographic data, living habits, socio-economic factors and complications. Univariate and multivariate logistic regression analysis was used to describe the odds ratio (OR) of the incidence of diabetes in different groups. Stratified analysis based on gender, age, and urban-rural region. All data is collected by trained researchers according to standardized protocols. Each questionnaire has a unique number, start and end time, and the investigator's signature on the cover. Due to the large amount of information collected, we removed unnecessary information such as commuting methods and children's work for our research purposes, while retaining information such as demographic characteristics, health status, social participation, family life, psychology, etc.
metadata.instructions: File naming method: 1. Table: 1.1 table 1, 1.2 table 2, 1.3 table 3, 1.4 table 4, 1.5 table 5, 1.6 table 6, 1.7 table 7 2. Picture: 2.1 Figure 1, 2.2 Figure 2, 2.3 Figure 3, 2.4 Figure 4. Data reading method: xlsx files can be opened in Excel, jpg files can be directly opened, and doc files can be opened in Word.

Prevalence and potential risk factors of self-reported diabetes among elderly people in China: A national cross-sectional study of 224,142 adults. Front Public Health, 10:1051445. doi: 10.3389/fpubh.2022.1051445.

background: A growing aging population in China is one of the key challenges facing public healthcare in the country. In fact, China has already become an aging society. In 2019, there were 164.5 million citizens aged 65 or older, including 26 million aged 80 years or more. It is predicted that the total population will reach 1.40–1.44 billion by 2030 and 1.29–1.40 billion by 2050 according to a study by the Chinese Center for Disease Control (CDC). The proportion of elderly individuals aged 65 years or more was continuously increasing, from 6.96% in 2000 to 8.87% in 2010, and 13.50% in 2020; this age group will comprise 20% of the total population by 2033 and 30% by 2050 from the Fifth Population Census to the Seventh Population Census. Meanwhile, age-related diseases such as diabetes and complications will impose a significant burden on family and public healthcare systems. In 2019, it was estimated that 19.3% of people aged 65–99 years (135.6 million, 95% confidence interval (CI): 107.6–170.6 million) live with diabetes globally. Over the next two decades, the number of people with diabetes will grow from 195.2 million to 276.2 million worldwide. In 2015, diabetes cost US$ 1.31 trillion (95% CI 1.28–1.36), or 1.8% (95% CI 1.8–1.9) of the global economy. China has experienced a dramatic increase in diabetes prevalence, from 2.5% in 1994 to 9.7% in 2008, and to 11.6% in 2010. As of 2019, there are 116.4 million adults in China with diabetes, representing approximately 12.8% of its adult population.
research objective: From another perspective, this study comprehensively evaluated the prevalence of diabetes among elderly Chinese patients by biomedical factors (age, gender, smoking, alcohol consumption, sleep quality, exercise, comorbidities) and social-psychological factors (education level, marital status, living alone, medical insurance, gainful employment, economic status, and spiritual and cultural life) to find out the awareness and potential risk factors among elderly diabetes patients.
challenges: The limitations of this study may include the following aspects. Firstly, this is a cross-sectional study. And potential risk factor analysis is correlation analysis, not causality analysis. Secondly, we do not test blood sugar to distinguish the hidden diabetes and pre-diabetes, nor do we gather information of the control and treatment of diabetes among the elderly. There are biases from the older persons due to recall bias or cognitive impairment. Thirdly, some variables were not evaluated. The dimensions and number of variables were large, and there was a lack of assessment on presence and change of these modifiable lifestyles, before or after the diagnosis of diabetes.
methods: The present study is based on data from the fourth SSAPUR, which was an extensive and large investigation survey of elderly people in China (comprising individuals aged≥ 60 years, who were permanent residents and nationally representative; the survey was carried out for 1 month, from 1–31 August 2015. All data were collected by trained study personnel in accordance with standardized protocols. From a total of 224,142 cases, we excluded those with missing data, including 9,084 cases whose diabetes status was not clear and 17 individuals who had more than 10 missing independent variables. The statistical significance of differences was assessed using Chi-square analysis for categorical variables and a post hoc two-tailed Newman–Keuls test when two or more groups were compared. In univariate logistic regression analysis, demographic data (household registration, age, gender and education level), living habits (smoking, alcohol consumption, sleep quality and exercise), socioeconomic factors (medical insurance, gainful employment, poverty, economic status, public benefit activities, spiritual cultural life), and comorbidities (malignant tumor, cataract/glaucoma, hypertension, CCVD, COPD) were analyzed as independent variables. After that, statistically significant independent variables in the univariate logistic regression analysis were included in the multivariate regression analysis. Stratification analysis was also performed, based on gender, age, and residing in urban or rural areas.
dataset: The 2000 survey included 18,987 observations, the 2006 survey included 18,458 observations, and the 2010 survey included 18,689 observations. The present study is based on data from the fourth SSAPUR, which was an extensive and large investigation survey of elderly people in China (comprising individuals aged≥ 60 years, who were permanent residents and nationally representative; the survey was carried out for 1 month, from 1–31 August 2015. This investigation adopted a stratified multistage and probability proportional to size (PPS) sampling method, with regional sample sizes selected according to the area’s proportion of people aged 60 years or more.
findings: According to our study, diabetes prevalence is higher in economically developed provinces than in less developed ones. Meanwhile, compared to rural areas, urban areas had a higher prevalence of diabetes, according to our survey. In our study, Poor sleep quality is an independent risk factor for diabetes. Interestingly, the never-married group had significantly lower rates of diabetes than the married group. People with hypertension were significantly more likely to develop diabetes than those with normal blood pressure. The prevalence of diabetes in tumor patients and cataract/glaucoma patients was also higher than that in patients without these comorbidities.

Verification.Question: Does the data collection method involve a stratified multistage sampling technique?

Concept Completion.Question: What data collection methods are used to gather information about the prevalence of diabetes in elderly populations?
Concept Completion.Answer: stratified multistage and probability proportional to size (PPS) sampling method

Concept Completion.Question: Where is the diabetes prevalence higher according to the findings from surveys of elderly populations in China?
Concept Completion.Answer: economically developed provinces and urban areas

Concept Completion.Question: When was the fourth survey of elderly populations conducted to gather data on diabetes and its risk factors?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used in nationwide studies to assess the prevalence of a health condition among elderly populations?
Example.Answer: A nationwide study in China assessing diabetes prevalence among elderly populations used a stratified multistage and probability proportional to size (PPS) sampling method, with data collected by trained personnel over a one-month period following standardized protocols.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in collecting data on self-reported health conditions in elderly populations, and how was this addressed?
Example.Answer: One challenge in collecting data on self-reported diabetes among elderly populations is recall bias or cognitive impairment. This was addressed by employing trained personnel to ensure data collection was consistent and reliable, although the study acknowledges the inherent limitations of self-reported data in cross-sectional studies.

Example.Question: Could you give an example of how stratification might be utilized in analyzing health data from large population surveys?
Example.Answer: In the analysis of diabetes prevalence among elderly Chinese, stratification was employed based on gender, age, and urban or rural residence, allowing researchers to explore differences in prevalence and risk factors across these demographics.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the properties of the data collection methods used in surveying elderly populations for diabetes prevalence?
Feature Specification.Answer: large-scale nationwide cross-sectional study, trained study personnel, standardized protocols, demographic data, living habits, socioeconomic factors, comorbidities, stratified multistage sampling, probability proportional to size sampling method

Quantification.Question: What is the total number of elderly participants included in a nationwide cross-sectional study conducted from 2015 to 2022 in China?
How many elderly participants were excluded from the analysis due to missing data in the national survey?
What is the number of male and female participants included in the analysis of self-reported diabetes incidence among the elderly in China?

Definition.Question: What does 'stratified multistage and probability proportional to size (PPS) sampling method' mean in the context of data collection for elderly populations?
Definition.Answer: In the context of data collection for elderly populations, 'stratified multistage and probability proportional to size (PPS) sampling method' refers to a sampling technique that involves dividing the population into subgroups, or strata, and then performing multiple stages of selection within each stratum. The probability proportional to size (PPS) aspect means that the probability of selecting a sample is proportional to its size, ensuring that larger strata have a higher chance of being selected. This method is used to ensure that the sample is representative of the entire population, considering variations in the size of different strata.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the potential challenges in data collection when using self-reported measures for diabetes prevalence among elderly populations?
Interpretation.Answer: Using self-reported measures for diabetes prevalence among elderly populations may introduce biases such as recall bias or cognitive impairment, which can affect the accuracy of the data. Additionally, not testing blood sugar to identify hidden diabetes and pre-diabetes presents a challenge in fully assessing the prevalence and understanding the potential risk factors.

Interpretation.Question: How might stratified multistage sampling techniques impact the interpretation of diabetes prevalence data across different demographic groups?
Interpretation.Answer: Stratified multistage sampling techniques allow for more accurate representation and comparison across different demographic groups, such as urban versus rural residents, and different age and gender groups. This method helps in identifying variations in diabetes prevalence and risk factors within these stratified groups, leading to more nuanced insights.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying reasons for using a stratified multistage and probability proportional to size (PPS) sampling method in collecting data on the prevalence of diabetes among elderly individuals in China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The stratified multistage and probability proportional to size (PPS) sampling method was used to ensure that the sample was nationally representative and accurately reflected regional variations in the population of individuals aged 60 years or more. This technique helps in capturing a comprehensive picture of diabetes prevalence across different economic and geographic regions, considering the area's proportion of elderly people.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why might there be potential biases in the self-reported data on diabetes prevalence among the elderly population?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Potential biases in self-reported data could arise due to recall bias or cognitive impairment among the elderly participants. This may affect the accuracy of the information reported regarding their diabetes status, as well as other variables such as lifestyle habits and socioeconomic factors.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using a cross-sectional study design on the analysis of risk factors for diabetes among the elderly in China?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of a cross-sectional study design may limit the analysis to correlation rather than causality, as it does not capture changes over time or the progression of diabetes and its risk factors. Additionally, it might not identify hidden diabetes or pre-diabetes due to the lack of blood sugar testing, and there can be biases due to recall or cognitive impairment among participants.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the exclusion of certain variables, such as modifiable lifestyle factors, affect the robustness and applicability of findings related to diabetes prevalence in Chinese elderly?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Excluding certain variables, like modifiable lifestyle factors, could reduce the robustness of the findings by not accounting for important factors that could influence diabetes prevalence. It might also limit the applicability of the results, as these factors are crucial to understanding and addressing the causes and prevention of diabetes.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of employing a stratified multistage and probability proportional to size (PPS) sampling method on the representativeness of diabetes prevalence data among elderly populations in China?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Employing a stratified multistage and PPS sampling method ensures that the sample is representative of the elderly population across different regions, reflecting regional variations in diabetes prevalence. This method helps provide a more accurate and comprehensive understanding of diabetes prevalence and its associated factors in varying demographic and socioeconomic contexts.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary goal of utilizing a stratified multistage and probability proportional to size (PPS) sampling method in data collection involving elderly populations?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goal of utilizing a stratified multistage and probability proportional to size (PPS) sampling method is to ensure that the data collected is nationally representative of elderly populations aged 60 years or more, allowing researchers to draw meaningful conclusions about the prevalence of diabetes and its potential risk factors across different regions and demographics in China.

Goal Orientation.Question: What objectives might drive the exclusion of certain data points, such as those without clear diabetes status or with significant missing variables, from a dataset?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective behind excluding certain data points, such as those without clear diabetes status or with significant missing variables, is to enhance the reliability and validity of the analysis. By ensuring that the dataset is complete and accurate, researchers can perform more robust statistical analyses and draw more precise conclusions about diabetes prevalence and risk factors among the elderly population.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are employed to ensure the standardization and accuracy of data collection in large-scale epidemiological surveys focusing on elderly populations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: All data were collected by trained study personnel in accordance with standardized protocols during a nationwide cross-sectional survey.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are potential biases addressed during the data collection process in demographic and health surveys involving self-reported health conditions in elderly populations?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The cross-sectional nature of the study and potential biases such as recall bias or cognitive impairment among older participants were acknowledged as limitations.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What sampling techniques are utilized to ensure the representativeness of elderly populations in national surveys on health conditions like diabetes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A stratified multistage and probability proportional to size (PPS) sampling method was used, with regional sample sizes selected according to the area’s proportion of people aged 60 years or more.

Enablement.Question: What data collection techniques enable the comprehensive assessment of diabetes prevalence and potential risk factors among elderly populations in China?
Enablement.Answer: The data collection techniques involve a stratified multistage and probability proportional to size (PPS) sampling method, with data collected by trained study personnel following standardized protocols. This approach allows for the assessment of both biomedical and social-psychological factors related to diabetes prevalence among elderly individuals.

Enablement.Question: How do methodological approaches such as logistic regression and stratification analysis enable the identification of potential risk factors for diabetes in elderly populations?
Enablement.Answer: Methodological approaches such as univariate and multivariate logistic regression analyses allow for the identification of statistically significant independent variables, while stratification analysis based on gender, age, and urban or rural residency helps in understanding the nuanced differences in diabetes risk factors across different demographic groups.

Enablement.Question: What challenges in data collection and analysis must be addressed to enhance the accuracy of self-reported diabetes incidence among elderly Chinese populations?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges include potential recall bias or cognitive impairment among older participants, the lack of blood sugar testing to identify hidden diabetes or pre-diabetes, and the exclusion of certain modifiable lifestyle variables, which may affect the accuracy of self-reported diabetes incidence data.

Expectation.Question: Why might data collection efforts in large-scale surveys of elderly populations in China face challenges related to recall bias or cognitive impairment among participants?
Expectation.Answer: The challenges in data collection efforts, such as recall bias or cognitive impairment among elderly participants, may arise because the study involves self-reported data from individuals aged 60 and above. Elderly participants might have difficulties accurately recalling past information, leading to potential biases in the data collected.

Expectation.Question: What factors could contribute to the exclusion of certain variables or cases from datasets in studies assessing diabetes prevalence among the elderly?
Expectation.Answer: Factors contributing to the exclusion of certain variables or cases might include missing data on key variables such as diabetes status or independent variables. Additionally, the large number of variables and the need to focus on research objectives may lead to the omission of less relevant information.

Expectation.Question: Why might a stratified multistage sampling method be expected to enhance the representativeness of datasets in nationwide studies of elderly populations?
Expectation.Answer: A stratified multistage sampling method is expected to enhance representativeness because it allows for the inclusion of diverse regional and demographic segments of the population. This method ensures that sample sizes are proportional to the population distribution, thereby increasing the likelihood that the dataset accurately reflects the broader population's characteristics.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of the stratified multistage and probability proportional to size (PPS) sampling method in capturing a representative sample of elderly populations in China for diabetes prevalence studies?
Judgmental.Answer: The stratified multistage and PPS sampling method seems effective in capturing a representative sample due to its consideration of regional population proportions of those aged 60 and above. This method helps ensure that the sample reflects the national demographic distribution, which is essential for accurately assessing diabetes prevalence among elderly populations across different regions in China.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges do you foresee in using self-reported data for assessing diabetes prevalence among elderly populations, and how might these affect the reliability of the findings?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges in using self-reported data include potential recall bias, cognitive impairments, and the lack of objective measures like blood sugar tests to confirm diabetes status. These issues could lead to underreporting or misclassification of diabetes prevalence, affecting the reliability of the findings. Addressing these challenges would require integrating objective testing methods to validate self-reported data.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could future data collection strategies be improved to better understand the socioeconomic factors influencing diabetes prevalence among the elderly in China?
Judgmental.Answer: Future data collection strategies could be improved by incorporating longitudinal study designs to capture changes over time and address causality. Additionally, gathering more comprehensive data on modifiable lifestyle factors before and after diabetes diagnosis, as well as integrating qualitative methods to explore the social and cultural contexts affecting diabetes management, would provide deeper insights into the socioeconomic influences on diabetes prevalence.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how a dataset can be representative of a national population when some regions might have different diabetes prevalence rates.
Assertion.Answer: The dataset is based on a national survey that used stratified multistage and probability proportional to size (PPS) sampling, which ensures that the sample sizes for each region are proportional to the population of people aged 60 years or more in that area, thus aiming to make the dataset nationally representative.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure how the challenges of recall bias or cognitive impairment in elderly participants are addressed during data collection.
Assertion.Answer: The data collection process involved trained study personnel who followed standardized protocols, which likely included strategies to minimize recall bias and account for cognitive impairments, although specific methods to address these challenges are not detailed in the provided information.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how researchers determine which socioeconomic and biomedical factors are relevant for assessing diabetes risk.
Assertion.Answer: In the research, univariate logistic regression analysis was used to assess demographic, living habits, socioeconomic factors, and comorbidities as independent variables, with those found to be statistically significant subsequently included in multivariate regression analysis to determine their relevance to diabetes risk.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the key data collection techniques used in gathering information from a large sample of elderly individuals in China for diabetes prevalence studies.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data collection involved trained study personnel using standardized protocols across a nationally representative survey of elderly individuals aged 60 years and above. The survey was conducted over a month, utilizing a stratified multistage sampling method with probability proportional to size (PPS) sampling to select regional sample sizes based on the elderly population proportion.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in data collection and potential biases present in studies examining diabetes prevalence among the elderly in China.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges include the cross-sectional nature of the study, which only allows for correlation analysis rather than causality. There is also the absence of blood tests to detect hidden diabetes or pre-diabetes, and potential recall bias or cognitive impairment among older participants. Additionally, not all variables were evaluated, and there is a lack of assessment on lifestyle changes before or after diabetes diagnosis.
